author: bsandmann
title: P2P Transactions based on Trust
description: Lack of trust in places where there is no central marketplace with reviews and ratings facilitates fraud and leads to inefficient economies

f6_assessments.q0: The proposal presents a p2p trust model based on the issue of trust tokens. This measure is very similar to the ratings of a product on a website. There is empirical evidence that that high-rated items with a large rating can be considered as good. Therefore this protocol may support trust infrastructure in small-value transactions.
f6_assessments.q1: Proposer claims 8 plus years of experience in .net development and Kotlin. There is a very high chance that he will be able to completer the proposal. However, any references to his past work would have been very reassuring.
f6_assessments.q2: The proposal has three deliverables, A whitepaper explaining the protocol, Library, and a POC app. The fund requested is at the rate of $32 per hour which is very reasonable. Since the output is measurable and will be open domain the project is auditable and success can be measured based on how the community utilizes the library.

f6_assessments.q0: Relation to personal qualifications:  in my year long work in political organisations I have been both a treasurer of a political organisation and a financial auditor (someone that checks the books of an organisation to verify that all the funds proceedings are in order). Hence, I can bring in some competencies in evaluating the budgets in this category on their credibility and accountability. In addition to this, I'm a catalyst member and CA for quite some while and have generally a good understanding of the different topics of the ecosystem and of how the proposal process works and what good proposals need. The proposal identifies an important problem in the challenge that needs to be adressed. The solution seems beneficial to the Cardano ecosystem, is explained comprehensibly and matches the Key Metrics of the challenge well. Scalability should be provided considering the makeup of the system planned.
f6_assessments.q1:
The proposer is relatively new to Catalyst and does not provide verifiable credentials, thus it is difficult to assess whther he is up to the challenge. He seems to plan implementing the proposal all by himself and does not talk about the type and number of additional team members. 
The budget is outlined clearly and broken down into identifiable items and is reasonable to achieve the set goals. What is really appreciated is that the proposer wants to pay some of the costsout of his own pocket.
The proposal offers a timetable/roadmap to complete the work that is however not sufficiently detailed. The resources used are only described briefly.
f6_assessments.q2: The deliverables and milestones are defined, could however be more detailed. The problem and solution statements are well-made and comprehensible. Overall this proposal should have a medium-good auditability.

f6_assessments.q0:
The idea of giving people :trust: scores on successful transactions is pretty solid. It can boost the local or even larger scale economy and create decentralized ID - which would get more adapted in the world. 

Even though that its success depends on multiple factors, it is in alignment with the challenge goal.

Note. It would be nice to see some analysis behind the idea, to justify why it would be so impactful. Right now, the proposer predicts that - this can boost the economy - so it is required - it would be nice to have this assumption "somehow confirmed or verified or supported".

Rating given 4.
f6_assessments.q1:
The experience and the description of the proposal is confirming that the proposer has the relevant skill and experience. 

Nevertheless, this will be no one-man job, therefore a team - or its future version - should have been at least considered in the proposal. 

Rating given 4.
f6_assessments.q2:
The main auditable indicator is the open-source code, and possibly whitepaper preparation/finish. 

Among others, these are sufficient for audit, therefore we can easily track the progress and its final outcome.

Also, its success can be verified by a number of users.

Score given 5.

f6_assessments.q0: The proposer able to identify the problem that is need to be solved, which is the lack of trusted central marketplace in some places to perform P2P activities. The proposer able to describe the solution needed to solve this problem, with 'history of trust' by utilizing DID on Cardano. This solution aligned with the challenge settings, and will benefit the Cardano ecosystem by driving the use case and adoption.
f6_assessments.q1: The proposer, Björn Sandmann, have 8+ years experience in full stack development, and familiar with Atala PRISM SDK. However, he didn't provide his Linkedin profile so I had to search for it myself. However, it's still difficult for me to verify his previous work. From this proposal, he's able to explain in depth what are the problem that is needed to be solved, and also explain the detailed solution ideas by utilizing DID from Atala PRISM. He's able to explain the technical details regarding this, especially on how PRISM/SSI terminology is being used for both counter parties (the seller and the buyer). The budget is explained in details, from what features to be implemented and the work hours needed. Overall, from the proposer experience, roadmap and implementation details, and budget break downs is explained in detail and comprehensive. I have to mention Björn will put his own money into this project too. At the end, it is still a shy away from 5 star rating because I can't verify Björn experience. Providing Linkedin profile or Github profile would be helpful.
f6_assessments.q2: The roadmap is explained clearly, the metrics is laid out too. However, since it is still a work in progress type of work (the first 3 months still working on whitepaper and discussion with IOG/Emurgo), the achievement parameter will be changing. Hence, the audit process would have to be adaptable. The proposer will provide documentation and open source it, so it will be a transparent audit process.

solution: Enable trustful and private P2P market transaction by using a 'history of trust' in areas where no central marketplace solutions exist
experience: Björn Sandmann: 8+ years of full stack development with the .net Stack. Focused on identity and privacy solutions. Familiar with PRISM SDK
